conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, analyze the motion of the particle based on the acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows acceleration as a function of time.
The acceleration is positive a_0 from t = 0 to t = t_0/2.
The acceleration is zero from t = t_0/2 to t = t_0.
The acceleration is negative -a_0 from t = t_0 to t = 3t_0/2.
The acceleration returns to zero from t = 3t_0/2 to t = 2t_0.
The particle starts from rest, so initial velocity v_0 = 0.
From t = 0 to t = t_0/2, the velocity increases linearly due to constant positive acceleration, v = a_0 t.
From t = t_0/2 to t = t_0, the velocity remains constant because acceleration is zero, v = a_0 t_0/2.
From t = t_0 to t = 3t_0/2, the velocity decreases linearly due to constant negative acceleration, v = a_0 t_0/2 - a_0(t - t_0).
From t = 3t_0/2 to t = 2t_0, the velocity remains zero because acceleration is zero.
From t = 0 to t = t_0/2, position x = 1/2 a_0 t^2.
